pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 378, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 171, 183, 186]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 332, 209]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 171, 905, 185]]<|/det|>
0625/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 194, 905, 209]]<|/det|>
February/March 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 904, 230]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 247, 505, 262]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 292]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 292, 537, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 338, 226, 351]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 905, 520]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 548, 218, 561]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 564, 568, 610]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 774, 90]]<|/det|>
A student is asked to find the volume of a small irregularly shaped piece of rock.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 531, 120]]<|/det|>
The student has the following apparatus available.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 131, 902, 355]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 368, 808, 385]]<|/det|>
Which apparatus must the student use to find the volume of the small piece of rock?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 397, 360, 490]]<|/det|>
A balance and ruler B ruler only C balance and measuring cylinder D measuring cylinder only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 518, 96, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 518, 604, 535]]<|/det|>
A digital stop-clock measures time in minutes and seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 549, 729, 566]]<|/det|>
The stop-clock reads 00:50 when it is started (i.e. 00 minutes 50 seconds).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 579, 392, 596]]<|/det|>
It reads 02:10 when it is stopped.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 610, 915, 626]]<|/det|>
What is the shortest possible time that has passed between starting and stopping the stop-clock?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 638, 330, 654]]<|/det|>
A 1 minute 06 seconds

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 664, 330, 680]]<|/det|>
B 1 minute 20 seconds

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 691, 337, 706]]<|/det|>
C 2 minutes 10 seconds

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 717, 337, 732]]<|/det|>
D 3 minutes 00 seconds

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|> Four students are instructed to find the time it takes for a ball bearing to fall through a vertical height of 1.0 m. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 119, 452, 134]]<|/det|> Each student uses a different procedure. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 148, 490, 164]]<|/det|> Which student follows the correct procedure? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 177, 140, 193]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 177, 919, 208]]<|/det|> The student measures the time taken for the ball to fall 1.0 m five times. He then adds the times taken together and divides by five. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 218, 140, 235]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 218, 919, 249]]<|/det|> The student measures the time taken for the ball to fall 1.0 m five times. He then multiplies the times taken together and divides by five. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 259, 139, 275]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 259, 919, 290]]<|/det|> The student measures the time taken for the ball to fall 2.0 m. He then divides the time taken by two. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 300, 139, 316]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 300, 919, 331]]<|/det|> The student measures the time taken for the ball to fall 2.0 m five times. He then adds the times taken together and divides by ten. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 359, 96, 377]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 359, 605, 375]]<|/det|> The graph shows the motion of a car for a 5-second period. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 387, 655, 534]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 551, 920, 583]]<|/det|> Which row shows a time when the car is at rest and a time when it is moving at a constant speed? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 597, 567, 740]]<|/det|>
the car is at rest atthe car is moving at a constant speed at
A0.0 s2.0 s
B0.0 s4.0 s
C4.0 s0.0 s
D4.0 s2.0 s
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 768, 96, 787]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 768, 693, 784]]<|/det|> Which property of an object is a gravitational force acting on its mass? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 796, 217, 812]]<|/det|> 
A density

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 822, 260, 837]]<|/det|>

B surface area

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 848, 217, 863]]<|/det|>

C volume

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 874, 212, 889]]<|/det|>

D weight

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 97, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 364, 90]]<|/det|>
A stone has a weight of 5.7 N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 484, 120]]<|/det|>
The gravitational field strength \(g\) is \(9.8 \text{N/kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 375, 149]]<|/det|>
What is the mass of the stone?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 161, 710, 178]]<|/det|>
A \(0.58 \text{kg}\) B \(5.7 \text{kg}\) C \(56 \text{kg}\) D \(550 \text{kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 206, 94, 225]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 206, 339, 223]]<|/det|>
Which equation is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 235, 375, 370]]<|/det|>
A \(\text{mass} =\) acceleration force B \(\text{mass} =\) density \(\times\) volume C \(\text{mass} =\) force \(\text{impulse}\) D \(\text{mass} =\) kinetic energy velocity²

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 406, 96, 425]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 406, 458, 424]]<|/det|>
What is meant by the moment of a force?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 435, 374, 452]]<|/det|>
A the magnitude of the force

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 462, 374, 478]]<|/det|>
B the work done by the force

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 488, 416, 504]]<|/det|>
C the time for which the force acts

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 514, 392, 530]]<|/det|>
D the turning effect of the force

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 558, 96, 577]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 558, 752, 575]]<|/det|>
A mass of \(20 \text{kg}\) is held stationary by a rope passing over a frictionless pulley.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[355, 585, 643, 714]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 727, 378, 744]]<|/det|>
What is the force \(T\) in the rope?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 755, 703, 772]]<|/det|>
A \(10 \text{kg}\) B \(20 \text{kg}\) C \(100 \text{N}\) D \(200 \text{N}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 800, 107, 819]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 800, 902, 817]]<|/det|>
Which equation relates the work done \(W\) on an object by a force \(F\) when it moves a distance \(d\)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 829, 715, 855]]<|/det|>
A \(d = WF\) B \(d = \frac{F}{W}\) C \(F = \frac{d}{W}\) D \(F = \frac{W}{d}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 897, 91]]<|/det|>
A boy produces an average useful power output of 60W as he rides his bicycle for 2.0 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 473, 120]]<|/det|>
How much useful energy does he transfer?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 710, 148]]<|/det|>
A 0.50J B 30J C 120J D 7200J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 176, 107, 195]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 176, 881, 193]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a solid block resting on a bench. The dimensions of the block are shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 205, 688, 393]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 404, 902, 421]]<|/det|>
On which labelled surface should the block rest to produce the smallest pressure on the bench?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 432, 170, 448]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 458, 170, 475]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 465, 170, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>Q</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 485, 170, 503]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 510, 141, 527]]<|/det|>
<label>R</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 508, 477, 526]]<|/det|>
<pre>D P, Q and R produce the same pressure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 553, 107, 572]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 554, 489, 571]]<|/det|>
A skier is standing still on a flat area of snow.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[413, 581, 583, 702]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 715, 920, 747]]<|/det|>
The total weight of the skier is 550N. The total area of his skis in contact with the ground is \(0.015m^2.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 759, 586, 776]]<|/det|>
What is the pressure exerted on the ground by the skier?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 787, 760, 804]]<|/det|>
<pre>A 0.83N/m² B 8.3N/m² C 3700N/m² D 37000N/m²

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 500, 90]]<|/det|>
A force acts on an area to produce a pressure.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 489, 120]]<|/det|>
Which changes produce the same pressure?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 140, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 131, 487, 147]]<|/det|>
doubling the area and doubling the force

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 158, 480, 174]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 155, 477, 172]]<|/det|>
doubling the area and halving the force

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 184, 620, 200]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 180, 620, 197]]<|/det|>
doubling the area and making the force four times bigger

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 210, 477, 225]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 209, 477, 225]]<|/det|>
halving the area and doubling the force

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 254, 107, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 254, 695, 271]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a cylinder containing oxygen under high pressure.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 281, 528, 477]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 604, 507]]<|/det|>
The temperature of the cylinder and the oxygen decreases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 520, 920, 552]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes what happens to the pressure in the cylinder and gives the reason why the pressure changes?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 564, 707, 580]]<|/det|>
<pre>A The pressure decreases because the oxygen particles move faster.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 590, 757, 606]]<|/det|>
<pre>B The pressure decreases because the oxygen particles move more slowly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 616, 700, 632]]<|/det|>
<pre>C The pressure increases because the oxygen particles move faster.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 643, 752, 658]]<|/det|>
<pre>D The pressure increases because the oxygen particles move more slowly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 686, 107, 704]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 686, 635, 702]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes what happens during solidification?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 715, 560, 730]]<|/det|>
<pre>A Particles begin to move around each other easily.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 740, 492, 756]]<|/det|>
<pre>B Particles stop moving around each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 766, 772, 782]]<|/det|>
<pre>C The temperature of the particles continues to decrease during solidification.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 793, 764, 808]]<|/det|>
<pre>D The temperature of the particles continues to increase during solidification.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 875, 90]]<|/det|> Solids expand the ......1...... and the average separation between molecules is the ......2...... . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 918, 135]]<|/det|> Which words complete the sentence about the expansion of solids when they are heated, relative to liquids and gases? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 147, 395, 274]]<|/det|>
12
Aleastgreatest
Bleastsmallest
Cmostgreatest

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 303, 107, 322]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 303, 814, 320]]<|/det|> A girl blows some air into a party balloon and ties a knot to seal the air in the balloon. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 333, 635, 350]]<|/det|> The girl holds the sealed balloon above a hot convector heater. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 363, 670, 380]]<|/det|> She observes that the volume of the balloon increases significantly. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 393, 645, 410]]<|/det|> Which statement identifies the cause of this increase in volume? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 422, 413, 438]]<|/det|> A The air in the balloon contracts. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 408, 464]]<|/det|> B The air in the balloon expands. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 475, 458, 490]]<|/det|> C The material of the balloon contracts. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 453, 516]]<|/det|> D The material of the balloon expands.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> The graph shows what happens to the density of a substance as its temperature changes over time. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 115, 697, 339]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 352, 652, 370]]<|/det|> Which term describes the change of state taking place at time \(t_2\)? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 381, 220, 397]]<|/det|> **A** melting <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 408, 224, 423]]<|/det|> **B** freezing <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 434, 266, 448]]<|/det|> **C** condensation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 460, 210, 475]]<|/det|> **D** boiling <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 504, 107, 521]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 503, 568, 520]]<|/det|> A candle is used to heat some water in a glass beaker. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 530, 662, 693]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 706, 785, 723]]<|/det|> What is the main method of heat transfer through the glass and within the water? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 736, 537, 864]]<|/det|>
through the glasswithin the water
Aconductionconduction
Bconductionconvection
Cconvectionconduction
Dconvectionconvection

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>21</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 633, 90]]<|/det|>
Which equation enables the speed of a wave to be calculated?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 140, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 102, 410, 119]]<|/det|>
speed = amplitude × frequency

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 129, 420, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 127, 421, 144]]<|/det|>
speed = amplitude × wavelength

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 155, 420, 171]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 154, 421, 171]]<|/det|>
speed = frequency × wavelength

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 185, 141, 204]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 183, 325, 216]]<|/det|>
speed = \(\frac{\text{frequency}}{\text{wavelength}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 250, 107, 268]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 918, 120]]<|/det|> An athlete hears a starting pistol fire 1.5 seconds after she sees a puff of smoke from the pistol. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 565, 107, 583]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 565, 500, 583]]<|/det|>
An isolated metal sphere is positively charged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 594, 690, 612]]<|/det|>
It is then brought near to another isolated metal sphere that is neutral.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[176, 621, 819, 727]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 740, 920, 774]]<|/det|>
What happens to the charges on the neutral sphere as the positively charged sphere is brought close to it?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 785, 141, 803]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 785, 855, 803]]<|/det|>
Some positive charges move to the left and some negative charges move to the right.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 812, 141, 830]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 812, 855, 829]]<|/det|>
Some positive charges move to the right and some negative charges move to the left.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 839, 141, 857]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 839, 813, 856]]<|/det|>
Some positive charges move to the right, but the negative charges do **not** move.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 865, 141, 883]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 865, 804, 882]]<|/det|>
The positive charges do **not** move, but some negative charges move to the left.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 687, 90]]<|/det|> Which statement about alpha, beta and gamma emissions is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 136, 119]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 101, 528, 119]]<|/det|> Alpha-particles are lighter than beta-particles. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 128, 136, 145]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 127, 573, 145]]<|/det|> Beta-particles are **not** deflected by magnetic fields. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 760, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 150, 762, 168]]<|/det|> Gamma rays are more penetrating than alpha-particles and beta-particles. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 178, 732, 195]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 177, 732, 195]]<|/det|> Gamma rays are more ionising than alpha-particles and beta-particles. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 224, 107, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 224, 626, 241]]<|/det|> What is an effect of ionising nuclear radiation on living things? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 252, 260, 268]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 252, 260, 268]]<|/det|> cell mutation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 278, 270, 294]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 278, 270, 294]]<|/det|> electric shock <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 304, 388, 320]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 304, 388, 320]]<|/det|> internal cooling of body cells <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 330, 270, 346]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 330, 270, 345]]<|/det|> broken bones <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 374, 107, 393]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 374, 500, 392]]<|/det|> The diagram shows the Earth orbiting the Sun. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[277, 402, 720, 530]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 546, 920, 577]]<|/det|> Which row identifies and explains the correct season in the northern hemisphere on the Earth in position 1? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 590, 735, 718]]<|/det|>
seasonexplanation
Asummerthe northern hemisphere tilts away from the Sun
Bsummerthe northern hemisphere tilts towards the Sun

Dwinterthe northern hemisphere tilts towards the Sun
